text: Resolution adopted by the General Assembly on 2 April 2015
[on the report of the Fifth Committee (A/69/702/Add.1)]
69/273.	Procurement
The General Assembly,

Recalling its resolutions 54/14 of 29 October 1999, 55/247 of 12 April 2001, 57/279 of 20 December 2002, 58/276 and 58/277 of 23 December 2003, 59/288 of 13 April 2005, 60/1 of 16 September 2005 and 60/260 of 8 May 2006, section VII of its resolution 60/266 of 30 June 2006, its resolution 61/246 of 22 December 2006, section XIX of its resolution 61/276 of 29 June 2007, its resolution 62/269 of 20 June 2008, section IV of its resolution 65/289 of 30 June 2011 and its resolution 68/263 of 9 April 2014,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* its resolutions 54/14 of 29 October 1999, 55/247 of 12 April 2001, 57/279 of 20 December 2002, 58/276 and 58/277 of 23 December 2003, 59/288 of 13 April 2005, 60/1 of 16 September 2005 and 60/260 of 8 May 2006, section VII of its resolution 60/266 of 30 June 2006, its resolution 61/246 of 22 December 2006, section XIX of its resolution 61/276 of 29 June 2007, its resolution 62/269 of 20 June 2008, section IV of its resolution 65/289 of 30 June 2011 and its resolution 68/263 of 9 April 2014,

text: Having considered the report of the Secretary-General on United Nations procurement activities and the related report of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (ACABQ)
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions

textWithHighlights: *Having considered* the report of the {{Secretary-General}} on United Nations procurement activities and the related report of the {{Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions}},

text: Having also considered the note by the Secretary-General transmitting the report of the Joint Inspection Unit on the review of long-term agreements in procurement in the United Nations system and the related note by the Secretary-General transmitting his comments and those of the United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination thereon,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination

textWithHighlights: *Having also considered* the note by the {{Secretary-General}} transmitting the report of the {{Joint Inspection Unit}} on the review of long-term agreements in procurement in the {{United Nations system}} and the related note by the {{Secretary-General}} transmitting his comments and those of the {{United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination}} thereon,

text: Takes note of the report of the Secretary-General;
textWithHighlights: *Takes note* of the report of the {{Secretary-General}};

text: Endorses the conclusions and recommendations contained in the report of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions, subject to the provisions of the present resolution;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions

textWithHighlights: *Endorses* the conclusions and recommendations contained in the report of the {{Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions}}, subject to the provisions of the present resolution;

text: Reaffirms the need for the United Nations procurement system to be transparent, open, impartial and cost-effective, based on a competitive procedure and fully reflecting the international character of the United Nations;
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* the need for the {{United Nations}} procurement system to be transparent, open, impartial and cost-effective, based on a competitive procedure and fully reflecting the international character of the {{United Nations}};

text: Stresses that best value for money; fairness, integrity and transparency; effective international competition; and the interest of the United Nations remain the four general principles for United Nations procurement, and requests the Secretary-General to ensure that those principles are adhered to in all United Nations procurement activities;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Ensure adherence to UN procurement principles
deliverables.deliverable: ensure that those principles are adhered to

textWithHighlights: *Stresses* that best value for money; fairness, integrity and transparency; effective international competition; and the interest of the {{United Nations}} remain the four general principles for {{United Nations}} procurement, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to [[ensure that those principles are adhered to]] in all {{United Nations}} procurement activities;
uncertainties: Classifying the deliverable 'ensure adherence' under 'standards' is somewhat interpretive; it could alternatively be seen as a compliance/oversight action without a perfect category match.

text: Recognizes the progress made and the key initiatives undertaken by the Secretary-General to advance a strategic approach to procurement and enhance the acquisition process for critical requirements, and requests the Secretary-General to continue such initiatives;
textWithHighlights: *Recognizes* the progress made and the key initiatives undertaken by the {{Secretary-General}} to advance a strategic approach to procurement and enhance the acquisition process for critical requirements, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to continue such initiatives;
uncertainties: "to continue such initiatives" is a vague task; not annotated as a deliverable due to lack of specificity.

text: Recalls paragraph 8 of the report of the Advisory Committee, and requests the Secretary-General to provide information, in his future reports on the subject, on the impact of Umoja on the procurement process, including the elimination of duplicate procurement processes;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Information on impact of Umoja on procurement process

textWithHighlights: *Recalls* paragraph 8 of the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to [[provide information]], in his future reports on the subject, on the impact of Umoja on the procurement process, including the elimination of duplicate procurement processes;
uncertainties: Deliverable categorized as information_sharing; could arguably be treated as an update within future reports.

text: Notes the efforts made by the Secretary-General to establish the supply chain module in Umoja, also notes the improved governance of procurement functions to include procurement operations in peacekeeping missions, special political missions, offices away from Headquarters and tribunals, while establishing a clear responsibility and accountability framework, and requests the Secretary-General to provide enhanced visibility of information on vendors that are awarded contracts and purchase orders;
textWithHighlights: *Notes* the efforts made by the {{Secretary-General}} to establish the supply chain module in Umoja, also *notes* the improved governance of procurement functions to include procurement operations in peacekeeping missions, special political missions, offices away from Headquarters and tribunals, while establishing a clear responsibility and accountability framework, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to provide [[enhanced visibility of information]] on vendors that are awarded contracts and purchase orders;

text: Recalls paragraphs 11 and 12 of the report of the Advisory Committee, and requests the Secretary-General to address the challenges identified therein with regard to information and communications technology procurement;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions

textWithHighlights: *Recalls* paragraphs 11 and 12 of the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to address the challenges identified therein with regard to information and communications technology procurement;
uncertainties: "Advisory Committee" is assumed to refer to the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (ACABQ). No concrete deliverable extracted from "address the challenges" due to vagueness.

text: Welcomes the conclusion of the pilot project on the request for proposal exercise, and looks forward to information on the advantages and disadvantages of the practice of using both invitation to bid and request for proposal methodologies in the procurement of aviation services in the next report of the Secretary-General;
textWithHighlights: *Welcomes* the conclusion of the pilot project on the request for proposal exercise, and *looks forward to* information on the advantages and disadvantages of the practice of using both invitation to bid and request for proposal methodologies in the procurement of aviation services in the next report of the {{Secretary-General}};

text: Recalls paragraph 51 of its resolution 65/289, in which it requested that the Secretary-General ensure full transparency in developing the request for proposal methodology for the acquisition of air services, and requests the Secretary-General to ensure that the implementation of this methodology is fair and transparent, as appropriate;
textWithHighlights: *Recalls* paragraph 51 of its resolution 65/289, in which it requested that the {{Secretary-General}} ensure full transparency in developing the request for proposal methodology for the acquisition of air services, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to ensure that the implementation of this methodology is fair and transparent, as appropriate;
uncertainties: The directive to "ensure that the implementation of this methodology is fair and transparent" describes a quality of implementation rather than a concrete deliverable; therefore, no deliverable was extracted.

text: Also recalls paragraph 18 of the report of the Advisory Committee, and stresses the importance of developing a transparent system in the implementation of the electronic tendering pilot project that gives equal opportunity to all potential vendors, bearing in mind technology challenges in developing countries and countries with economies in transition, and requests the Secretary-General to submit an assessment of the pilot project in his next report on procurement;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (ACABQ)

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Assessment of the electronic tendering pilot project

textWithHighlights: Also *recalls* paragraph 18 of the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, and *stresses* the importance of developing a transparent system in the implementation of the electronic tendering pilot project that gives equal opportunity to all potential vendors, bearing in mind technology challenges in {{developing countries}} and {{countries with economies in transition}}, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to submit an [[assessment of the pilot project]] in his next report on procurement;
uncertainties: Assumed the “Advisory Committee” refers to the ACABQ. Treated the requested output as an analysis deliverable (assessment) rather than a separate report, since it is to be included in the Secretary-General’s next report on procurement.

text: Welcomes the continuation of the independent procurement challenge system, the Award Review Board, and its phased expansion to also cover offices away from Headquarters, regional commissions and tribunals, and peacekeeping and special political missions, and requests the Secretary-General to provide in his next report an update on the development of the Board, including on the feasibility of lowering the financial threshold for vendors to submit a procurement challenge;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: update on Award Review Board development
feasibility analysis of lowering vendor financial threshold for procurement challenges
deliverables.deliverable: feasibility of lowering the financial threshold

textWithHighlights: *Welcomes* the continuation of the independent procurement challenge system, the {{Award Review Board}}, and its phased expansion to also cover offices away from Headquarters, {{regional commissions}} and tribunals, and peacekeeping and special political missions, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to provide in his next [[report]] an [[update]] on the development of the Board, including on the [[feasibility of lowering the financial threshold]] for vendors to submit a procurement challenge;
uncertainties: Considered whether to treat the “next report” as an independent deliverable versus only the “update” within it; included both conservatively, plus the feasibility analysis as a separate analysis deliverable.

text: Notes with appreciation the efforts of the Secretary-General and the overall progress made in strengthening internal controls in procurement, including improved vendor management, with an emphasis on fostering a culture of ethics and integrity among staff members and vendors;
textWithHighlights: *Notes with appreciation* the efforts of the {{Secretary-General}} and the overall progress made in strengthening internal controls in procurement, including improved vendor management, with an emphasis on fostering a culture of ethics and integrity among staff members and vendors;

text: Recalls paragraph 28 of the report of the Advisory Committee, requests the Secretary-General to ensure transparency in conducting the activities of the Vendor Review Committee, and looks forward to continued reporting on the activities of that Committee in his future reports;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Ensure transparency in Vendor Review Committee activities
Continued reporting on Vendor Review Committee activities

textWithHighlights: *Recalls* paragraph 28 of the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to [[ensure transparency]] in conducting the activities of the {{Vendor Review Committee}}, and *looks forward to* [[continued reporting]] on the activities of that Committee in his future reports;
uncertainties: Classifying “ensure transparency” as a deliverable fits best under policy, though it could arguably be seen as standards/process oversight.

text: Also recalls paragraph 25 of the report of the Advisory Committee, and requests the Secretary-General to intensify his efforts to promote procurement from developing countries and countries with economies in transition, so as to develop a vendor roster that is more representative of the membership of the Organization, and to report thereon in his next progress report on United Nations procurement activities;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Update in next progress report on procurement activities

textWithHighlights: Also *recalls* paragraph 25 of the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to intensify his efforts to promote procurement from {{developing countries}} and {{countries with economies in transition}}, so as to develop a [[vendor roster]] that is more representative of the membership of the Organization, and to [[report thereon]] in his next progress report on United Nations procurement activities;
uncertainties: Classifying “vendor roster” as infrastructure is somewhat interpretive; it could arguably be seen as a policy/administrative instrument rather than a system.

text: Requests the Secretary-General to continue to explore additional innovative ways to promote procurement from developing countries and countries with economies in transition at Headquarters and field offices, and to report on concrete measures taken in this regard;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Explore innovative ways to promote procurement from developing countries and economies in transition

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to continue to [[explore additional innovative ways]] to promote procurement from {{developing countries}} and {{countries with economies in transition}} at Headquarters and field offices, and to [[report]] on concrete measures taken in this regard;
uncertainties: Classified “explore additional innovative ways” as an analysis-type deliverable, though it is somewhat broad.

text: Recognizes the efforts by the Secretariat to increase the number of business seminars in developing countries, and requests the Secretary-General, in his capacity as Chair of the United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination, to encourage the entities of the United Nations system to participate in the business seminars in developing countries and countries with economies in transition;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination (CEB)
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination

textWithHighlights: *Recognizes* the efforts by the {{Secretariat}} to increase the number of business seminars in {{developing countries}}, and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>>, in his capacity as Chair of the {{United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination}}, to encourage the entities of the {{United Nations system}} to participate in the business seminars in {{developing countries}} and {{countries with economies in transition}};
uncertainties: Did not extract a deliverable for the 'requests' clause because the concrete task is to 'encourage' participation (vague/indirect), while actual participation would be by UN system entities not directly tasked by the Assembly.

text: Requests the Secretary-General to encourage interested local vendors to apply for registration on the United Nations Secretariat vendor roster, with a view to broadening its geographical base;
textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to encourage interested local vendors to apply for registration on the {{United Nations Secretariat}} vendor roster, with a view to broadening its geographical base;

text: Recalls paragraph 34 of the report of the Advisory Committee, decides to establish the Regional Procurement Office in Entebbe, Uganda, as a regular office within the Procurement Division of the Secretariat, and looks forward to receiving updates on the functions of the Office in the context of the global service delivery model;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Regional Procurement Office in Entebbe, Uganda

textWithHighlights: *Recalls* paragraph 34 of the report of the {{Advisory Committee}}, *decides* to establish the [[Regional Procurement Office]] in Entebbe, Uganda, as a regular office within the Procurement Division of the {{Secretariat}}, and *looks forward* to receiving updates on the functions of the Office in the context of the global service delivery model;
uncertainties: "Advisory Committee" likely refers to the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (ACABQ), which is not explicitly listed; normalized as "Other (Other United Nations Bodies)". The deliverable type for establishing an office is treated as "infrastructure"; one could argue it is an organizational/policy action.

text: Requests the Secretary-General not to proceed with a pilot project on sustainable procurement at this time;
textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> not to proceed with a pilot project on sustainable procurement at this time;

text: Notes with satisfaction the efforts made by the Secretariat to implement joint procurement with United Nations system organizations, and emphasizes that, when it does so, the four general principles of financial regulation 5.12 of the Financial Regulations and Rules of the United Nations shall apply;
textWithHighlights: *Notes with satisfaction* the efforts made by the {{Secretariat}} to implement joint procurement with {{United Nations system organizations}}, and *emphasizes* that, when it does so, the four general principles of financial regulation 5.12 of the Financial Regulations and Rules of the {{United Nations}} shall apply;
uncertainties: No assignees or deliverables appear; "emphasizes ... shall apply" is treated as reinforcing rather than a directive instruction.

text: Acknowledges recommendation 5 of the report of the Joint Inspection Unit.
textWithHighlights: *Acknowledges* recommendation 5 of the report of the {{Joint Inspection Unit}}.

text:
84th plenary meeting
2 April 2015
